titleStmt.title: The Seconde Part of the Unfortunate Florinda

publicationStmt.p: Encoded for HIST 630: Digital Methods for Historical Research, Texas A&M University, Spring 2023.

msContents.p: Document is two loose leaves, handwritten in italic on both recto and verso.

body.ab:
After the Marriage of this incomparable
paire kingeRodarigoe commanded the
noble Alphonso to (servant and constant
lover tofflorinda) to accompany the
valliant Ithocles into Barbary with a
hundred gallantnoblemen and gentlemen in
his traine hag haveinge with much im
portunity prevailed with the new mar
ride kinge and Queene to staye in the
Court of Spaine tell the return of the
honourd Ithocles so Alphonso who could
not in honour refuse itt allthough hee
was too certane to that hee should leve
his Lovely fflorinda to bee tossed between
the violant unlawfull love of the kinge and the im
placable l maleace of Alonsoe in a far great
ter hazard of the wrack of her honour
then a new built ffriggett in a hurricanio
beutween the wherleinge scilla and the
cragged Caribdis but she haveinge renew
ed her but hee with reitterated assurerances
of her fedelitty took his fatall and (not only
soe) but his finall) leve of this lovely virgin her
for allthough hee did afterwards see her
yett she had lost that part virgin beauty
which she too well knew made her amiable
in the eyes of all after their im
thus takeinge
after them imbarkinge the kingeRodorigo
and his faire Quene did sett them selves wholely
teo entertaine the ffrench Kinge and Queen
with all plesant devertisments still hee

hee still watchinge for any opertunity to finde
the faire fflorinda alone who was as vigilent
to prevent itt, till one night after supper
(night beeinge fittest for deeds of darkness)
they beeinge all a danceinge the kinge
was soe unable to resiste t hide the violance
of his affection that poore fflorinda was affraid itt
would bee decerned th by the (yett unsusspi
sus) Queene, for hee did nothinge but court
or dance with hir which soe hugely afflicted
this inoscent virgin that she haveinge ended
the dance tooke Castabella by the hand and
slip’d out of the roome but shee was noe soon
ner gon then mist by the amorous kinge
who presantly went after and found them
walkinge in a Gallary o Cast ladye sayde hee your are
call’d for by the Queene att which word
they hasted awaye but before fflorinda
could follow castabella the k lasivious kinge
laide hold of her arme, sayeinge staye the
faire fflorinda for now and see mee die
with the influence skorn of those yr eyes of thyne
in whose influence thou art soe cruell as not
to suffer mee to live then clapeinge too the
doore which had a springe locke hee said
now I see that you are soe ungratefull as
to vallew that trf imaginary triffelinge, bubble honour
above not only your own happiness but
my liffe allsoe, longeinge I beleeve to see
mee lie dead att your feett, then drawinge
out his sworde hee as iff hee intended to
kill himselfe, hopeing by this ehigh passion to
prevaile but shee (in much feare) mildly
replide itt iff itt must bee soe itt is much
better to die Inoscente then to survive in
that guilt which will bee your inevitable
and eternall ruen. o but fflorinda saide hee
nature commandes us to preserve ouer essenc
which is not possible for mee to doe with out the inioye
ment of thee which iff I maye willingly
ob

obtaine my self and kingedome wille bee
att thy command. she sweetlye re answered that all the
kingdomes w (not only on this Orbe but the
worlds in every starr) weere of too inconsider
able waight andvallew when vertue was laide in the scoles
naye then saide the inraged kinge iff you will
not yeald upon honourable termes I must take
you by storm, and notwithstandinge all
her praires and tears, and scrameinge and
striveinge beeinge much stronger the shee
hee violated the unfortunate fflorinda
who still thundred breathed out curses and depre
cations against hiem call and wilth with
floods of tears implored vengence devine
vengence. soe that no w the kinge found itt
as dificult to still her complaints as before
to perswaide her till the Divell (or his own
cursed nature) e wores Divell the two promtei ng him hee said my
Deare fflorinda my I have soe much affection
for thee that iff thou willt but conceal this
m violent expression of my love I will per
forme more then I att first I did promise, but iff
you still refuse my love I will immediately
fectch up the most deformed negro slave in
my black gard and make him deflower you
and then run my sword throug you both nd then ll p up the inge and ueene to spectateres in who nnot but plaude my stis soe
I hath at you maye die shall you die in horred imfamey poore
fflorinda who had thus whose saul did boyle
with revenge and beeinge lothe to leve all
infamie upon her name,
poore fflorinda whose soul boyelinge with revenge
tho and abhorringe Imfamey thought best
to return this desemblinge replie. sir I can not
but loock upon this violance of yours as proceederinge
from an unresistable Passion and shall willingely
ioyne with you in consealeing concealeinge itt lest
the knowledge of itt should bee an d eternall
Corrisive to the harts of my deare and tender harted
Parents who perhapps maye not bee soe reddy
to excuse you as I who have all alonge know
bin but too scenceable of your sufferinge thus

Thus shee poore soule suffered her selfe to bee
imbraced by him (whon her soule did soe infinitely
abhor:) for that certanly the clauinge of a lion or
grips of a tigur, or clinginges of serpentes
was much more pleaseinge to her: but she
in hope to live to revenge her di shonour
accted so itt soe well that hee beleeved all
all to bee reall soe she desired leve (because
she was very much discumposed) to goe
to her chamber hee promiseinge her to excuse
her to the Queenes: which hee did tellinge
them that she (not beeinge very well) was
gon to bead, but the vertous Castabella was
(not soe satisfide) hastned after and fownd her
in bead and as She thought asleepe soe she
went souftly to bead to her but when their
atendents were gon and they two all alone
then the wronged fflorinda whose sorrow as
was more then she was able to containe,
with huge ffloodes of teares burst out in to
this sad acclamation. Oh Castabella happie
Castabella: that maye now even att this very minute hower
exeire ex pire a happie a hiappie Virgin could
I doe soe I would not breath a one minnute
but wooes is mee I live (or rather live in
(dieinge live) in horred Infamie, but iff C
but oh you Celestiall Powers lett mee but
live to bee revenged and then welcone
anihillation oh welcome eternall death
or a nihillation. then Castabella (who now
but too well knew what had befallen her)
did sympathiseinge with her in her sorrow and
sufferinge) said ah deare fflorinda lett not
the sinne of others provoke you (by revenge
full thoughts) to sully your unspotted virgin
soule: which remains still in itts vergin
Purity: ah replide she I thought youre had
had affection had bin soe much had soe much
affection for mee and had bin soe
